results.title: Before the rain = Pred dozhdot
results.creator_credit: AIM, Noe Productions, Vardar Films, Judy Counihan, Cedomir Kolar, Sam Taylor and Milcho Manchevski
results.headline_credit: Macedonia, The Former Yugoslav Republic Of, 1994
results.brief_description: Subtitled ‘A Tale in Three Parts’, Milcho Manchevski’s debut feature film tells three stories dealing with the ancestral ethnic rivalry eating at the heart and soul of the newly formed republic of Macedonia. The first tale follows the fate of young Orthodox monk Kiril (Gregoire Colin) as he attempts to shelter a young Albanian girl from the wrath of the local villagers, thus unleashing the full might of a long-standing ethnic feud onto the monastery. The second tale is set in London where Anne (Katrin Cartlidge) is considering leaving her husband to live with Aleksander (Rade Serbedzija), a world-weary war correspondent, who has just returned just from Bosnia. The last tale documents Aleksander’s road back to the Macedonian village of his youth. Tired of photographing war, Aleksander, finds his home on the brink, with tensions between Macedonian and Albanian villagers at an all time high. (Awards: Winner of the Best Film Prize at the 1994 Venice Film festival). Manchevski was at pains to explain at the time of release that his film was not a documentary on Macedonia or the Balkans, as the tension described in ‘Before the Rain’, could erupt anywhere, anytime. In Macedonian with English subtitles.

results.title: Before sunrise
results.creator_credit: Castle Rock Entertainment, Detour Filmproduction, F I L M H A U S, Anne Walker-McBay and Richard Linklater
results.brief_description: This romantic comedy, set in Vienna, is essentially a two-hander with a simple but effective set-up. Jesse (Ethan Hawke) is an American tourist who, travelling on the Budapest to Vienna train, meets French grad student, Celine. When Jesse reveals he plans to roam Vienna, awaiting his morning flight back to the US, Celine spontaneously decides to spend the night with him walking and talking, discovering the city and each other. Linklater’s romantic comedy works exceptionally well - his camera sits intimately and comfortably with his protagonists as they converse about family, ambition, death, life, love and sex. The deft and funny script explores the possibilities of two people forming an attraction over the course of a fortuitous day, without stooping to typical rom-com tropes that tend to mar the genre. Linklater (Dazed and confused, Slacker, SubUrbia, Waking life, Tape), who for a time specialised in films that addressed the concerns of Generation X, presents a brief encounter that is talky, urbane, wistful, understated, reflective, poignant and romantic.

results.title: Before night falls [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Grandview Pictures, Jon Kilik and Julian Schnabel
results.brief_description: Before night falls is Julian Schnabel’s second feature, his follow-up to “Basquiat”. The story of Cuban poet and writer Reinaldo Arenas, the screenplay is based on Arenas’ memoirs. The film opens with Arenas’ idyllic, if impoverished youth - brought up by his adoring mother and a dictatorial father who forbade his son’s poetry. A shift to the city exposes Arenas to urban influences and his teachers encourage his artistic expression. Openly gay and politically active, the adult Arenas finds himself persecuted by the Castro regime and his writing is smuggled to France in order to be published. Javier Bardem plays Arenas as a passionate, talented hedonist whose attempts to escape incarceration are both daring and foolhardy. The cinematography depicts Cuba as a magical and beautiful place, saturated in decaying splendour, which is crippled by corruption and state sanctioned police brutality. Schnabel employs an episodic structure to relay the key moments of Arenas’ life. Cuba - a place teeming with culture, food, love, sex and passion - is contrasted with Arenas’ ‘freedom’ in New York. Despite his liberation Arenas is depressed, living austerely and the scenes take on a bleached aesthetic, reflecting perhaps the writer’s longing for his rich homeland.

results.title: Bedrooms and hallways [Widescreen]
results.creator_credit: Berwin and Dempsey Productions, Ceci Dempsey, Dorothy Berwin and Rose Troche
results.brief_description: Rose Troche’s (“Go Fish”) second feature film is a gentle and amusing study into the nuances of sexual preference, dating and masculinity. Using Leo’s (Kevin McKidd) 30th birthday bash as a basis, the film traces Leo’s relationship to the guests; gay room mate Darren (Tom Hollander) and his real estate agent boyfriend (Hugo Weaving) with a penchant for using the bedrooms of the houses he’s selling for their trysts; straight and single friend Angie (Julie Graham); new Age guru and leader of Leo’s men’s group, Keith (Simon Callow); Leo’s previous boyfriend, Brendan (James Purefoy) and Brendan’s current girlfriend, Sally (Jennifer Ehle), who also happens to be Leo’s high school sweetheart. Central to the film are the gatherings of the men’s group for masculine assertiveness and when Leo admits his attraction to seemingly straight, Irishman Brendan, it opens the floodgates for other members of the group with surprising results. (Awards: Winner Audience Award, London Film Festival, 1998)

results.title: Bedknobs and broomsticks
results.brief_description: Angela Lansbury plays a prim and proper Eglantine Price, an amateur English witch who joins up with three cockney waifs to help save war-torn Britain from Nazi invaders. A film for all ages, Bedknobs and Broomsticks features ingenious animation, a hilarious soccer game where crocodiles, elephants, and other animals really kick up a storm. Brass beds fly, nightgowns dance, and airborne brooms sweep away young and old alike to a fun-filled world of fantasy.

results.title: Bed and board = Domicile conjugal
results.creator_credit: Fida Cinematografica, Films du Carrosse, Valoria, Francois Truffaut and Marcel Berbert
results.brief_description: Fourth instalment in Francois Truffaut’s “Antoine Doinel” series depicts the still somewhat immature Antoine facing the birth of his first child, infatuation with a Japanese woman and the petty squabbles of married life. Whilst perhaps not as well realised as “Stolen kisses”, “Bed and board” nevertheless maintains a laconic charm, aided by the redoubtable Truffaut mainstay, Jean-Pierre Leaud.

results.title: Beauty and the beast: the enchanted christmas
results.creator_credit: Disney Television Animation and Andy Knight
results.brief_description: Belle vows to bring a little of the Christmas spirit into the Beast’s castle, even though he has lots of misgivings about the success of her plans. All the enchanted objects chip in, even the reluctant Angelique, a beautiful tree ornament. The evil Forte, a pipe organ wants to undo all of Belle’s plans and so spoil Christmas for everyone, but as in all good fairy tales, it all ends up happily ever after with the Christmas spirit intact.

results.title: Beautiful girls
results.creator_credit: Miramax Films, Woods Entertainment, Cary Woods and Ted Demme
results.brief_description: A ten year high school reunion in a snowbound town is the setting for this exploration of how men’s lives are influenced by “beautiful girls”. Piano playing Willie (Hutton), former heartthrob Tommy (Dillon), his girlfriend Sharon (Sorvino), and his lover Darian (Holly) all gather with long lost friends for reminiscing and advice about relationships. Out of the group of friends, only Willie has moved away from the small New England town and is pursuing a career as a piano player. He is at a crossroads in his life, contemplating giving up his career for girlfriend Tracy (Annabeth Gish). His feelings are complicated by the presence of a captivating young girl next door (Natalie Portman).

results.title: Beat the devil
results.creator_credit: Romulus Films, Santana, Jack Clayton and John Huston
results.brief_description: The story of a motley group of swindlers travelling on an Africa-bound tramp steamer. The plot unfolds to reveal a web of double crossing and deception as each attempts to get their hands on a fortune in uranium deposits. Starring Gina Lollobrigida and Humphrey Bogart. Written by Truman Capote and John Huston from a novel by James Helvick.

results.title: Beat Street
results.creator_credit: Orion Pictures Corporation, David V. Picker, Harry Belafonte and Stan Lathan
results.brief_description: Ramon is a Puerto Rican graffiti artist who hangs with numerous rap and hip-hop artists whilst marking time in the Bronx. His friends, a mix of rappers, dancers and turntablists, yearn to stage a huge hip-hop concert and give voice to their artistic expression. On the cusp of adulthood, the teenagers face all manner of trials, including fledging romances and the stigma of their class, as they face the future. Despite its dated aesthetic, “Beat Street” is a lot of fun, and quite exuberant as it travels from one snappy musical moment to the next. This film is also an interesting view of the Bronx as it existed in the 1980s - a fascinating melting pot of backgrounds, set against the grimy subways, graffiti work, and an underground music and dance scene. Cast includes: Rae Dawn Chong, Guy Davis, John Chardiet, Leon Grant and Robert Taylor. Kool Herc, Kool Moe Dee, The Rock Steady and NY Breakers, Us Girls, Busy Bee, Melle Mel and the Furious Five, Bambaataa & Soul Sonic Force, Tina B., Brenda Starr, Treacherous Three and Doug E. Fresh are among the artists that make an appearance.
